source.description: REAGENTS & SOLUTIONS TO PREPARE BEFOREHAND

LB medium
Tryptone
Yeast extract
Add ultrapure H2O and mix until dissolved; check if
and adjust with NaOH if required.

source.body: Add agar if making solid LB agar.

To pour LB agar plates:
  • Melt agar in the microwave if required (loosen the lid).
  • Place into a water bath at and allow agar to equilibrate to this temperature (at least ).
  • In the flow hood, add carbenicillin and mix gently.
  • Poor approximately into each plate.
  • Leave with lids off to set for approximately .
  • Store plates for up to 2-3 weeks in a sealed bag in the fridge (no parafilm).

CAUTION – always watch the microwave when melting agar and never leave the area. The agar will become super-heated and can boil over very easily. Wear protective gloves.
CAUTION – never place anything cold (e.g. magnetic stirrer) into super-heated molten agar.

Strep-Tactin Sepharose 50% suspension

  • Fill the glass column with the resin [it comes in 50% suspension in buffer W (from step 1.6), so it is already in the buffer that will be used later for purification (check below)].

source.body: Always work at . If it is not possible to perform chromatography at and column needs to be transferred to air bubbles may form since cold storage buffer is able to take up more gas than buffers at . Therefore, it is recommended to equilibrate the columns immediately after exposure to higher temperatures with buffer that is equilibrated at such temperature.

CELL GROWTH & COLLECTION
Day 1
1. Inoculate the cultures with a small volume of cells using a sterile tip onto the plate containing LB medium with
carbenicillin.
2. Incubate plates upside down
(approx. 9h) at
.
Day 2
3. Add
carbenicillin into
LB in a 50 mL Falcon tube.
4. Pick a single colony from the plate and add into the LB.
5. Shake
(approx. 9h) at
.
Day 3
6. Prepare a glycerol stock of the culture (for long term storage): combine
culture +
30% glycerol in a 2 mL screw-cap tube, mix gently by inversion.

source.body: Transformed E. coli cells stored as frozen glycerol stocks are used as inoculums for starter cultures. Keep glycerol stock .
For large cultures do the above procedure in 4 Falcon tubes to get 40 mL of culture.

source.description:
INDUCTION
Day 3
7. Dilute 1:50 in 1 L Erlenmeyer flask (
of culture in a final volume of
).
8. Grow cells at
under continuous stirring at 225 rpm.
9. Check optical density at 600 nm after
incubation, and keep checking regularly until the cells reach an optical density of approx. 0.8 at 600 nm (for the large culture it took ~
).
10. Remove
aliquot before adding IPTG for SDS-Page of uninduced and induced expression. Centrifuge, discard supernatant and keep at
for later.
11. Induce dPGM expression by adding
IPTG to the cell culture (
of
IPTG in
).
12. Maintain the culture at
under continuous stirring.
Day 4
13. Transfer
culture to two 500 mL centrifuge bottles on ice.
14. Collect the cells by centrifuging at
. Discard supernatant. Repeat using the same 500 mL bottles until the entire culture content is collected in the two bottles.
15. Suspend the accumulated cell pellets in about
of buffer A. Pool the cell suspension and distribute into 2x 50 mL screw cap tubes (
). Rinse the 500 mL bottles with about
of buffer A and add in the 50 mL tubes as well.
16. Centrifuge at
Discard supernatant and dry the tubes as much as possible. The wet cell pellets are stored at
until extraction.

source.body: Tests were done at and . Both had good results but at more protein was produced.

source.description:
LYSIS
Day 5 (long day)
17. Thaw pellets
(freeze-thaw cycle).
18. Suspend the cell pellets to about
of wet cell pellet weight to lysis buffer.
19. Vortex and keep
.
20. Transfer the cells to a beaker. Rupture the cells and DNA by sonicating the suspension until solution becomes easy to pipette. Insert sonicator half way into the solution and apply 3 x 45s bursts, maintaining the beaker always
. Pause for 30s between each burst.
21. Centrifuge at
. Keep supernatant (and pellet for SDS-Page checking).
22. Analyse the expression of dPGM as soluble polypeptides in the uninduced and induced samples by SDS-PAGE (Appendix 2).

source.body: Transfer tube with pellets to in the evening before. , keep pellet upside down, not directly touching ice to thaw faster.
E.g. if pellet weighs 2.694 g, add 13.47 mL buffer.

It is useful to verify the expression of dPGM as insoluble and soluble polypeptides in the uninduced and induced samples by SDS-PAGE. It is expected that the protein will be in the soluble fraction but occasionally it may be in the insoluble fraction (see Appendix 2 for SDS-PAGE).

source.description:
PRECIPITATION
23. Measure the volume of supernatant and add saturated ammonium sulfate to
24. Add the saturated ammonium sulfate drop-wise to the supernatant while stirring continuously using a separatory funnel in a ring stand. Stir for
.
25. Collect precipitated material by centrifugation at
(slow brake).

source.body: Vol saturated ammonium sulfate for 80% saturation = (Vol supernatant / 0.2) - Vol supernatant

blocks.text: Vol saturated ammonium sulfate for 80% saturation = (Vol supernatant / 0.2) - Vol supernatant

source.description:
RESUSPENSION
26. Suspend pellets in a total volume of
of buffer A
, mixing well using a 1 mL pipette.
27. Centrifuge at
to clean any remaining debris and be easier to flow through Sephadex G-25 fine column

source.body: If more than one tube, resuspend one and do the resuspension of the next one with the content of the first one, to reduce the volume produced. If needed, add more buffer.

blocks.text: If more than one tube, resuspend one and do the resuspension of the next one with the content of the first one, to reduce the volume produced. If needed, add more buffer.

source.description:
DESALTING
28. After equilibrating Sephadex G-25 fine column with buffer A (2 x column volumes) and with lysis buffer (1 x column volume), load the sample and elute with lysis buffer, taking aliquots and checking the amount of protein with Bradford reagent (monitor the development of blue colour by eye for a qualitative assessment, not necessary to read absorbance).
29. Pool samples with highest protein content.
30. Once desalting of the sample is complete, wash column with 2 column volumes of
NaOH, rinse with water, and re-equilibrate with 2-3 column volumes of buffer A.

source.body: Start adding of buffer A and collecting the aliquots. Check TSP “by eye” and when it gets blue reduce to elutions, until the aliquot has low protein content. The objective is to collect as much protein as possible without diluting the sample more than is necessary.

For storage, antimicrobial agents should be added to the column to prevent contamination ( phenyl mercuric salts, thimerosal, chlorobutanol, chlorhexine, sodium azide, or ethanol are acceptable).
When necessary, the gel can be removed from the column and sterilized by autoclaving.

source.description:
PURIFICATION & ELUTION
31. Purification and elution of dPGM uses a Strep-tactin Sepharose,
bed column, as detailed in the manufacturer’s instructions:

source.body: For purification and regeneration of Strep-tactin resin, see Appendices 3 and 4.

source.description:
PRECIPITATION
32. Measure the volume of supernatant and add saturated ammonium sulfate to
33. Add the saturated ammonium sulfate drop-wise to the supernatant while stirring continuously using a separatory funnel in a ring stand. Stir for 30 min.
34. Collect precipitated material by centrifugation at
(slow brake).
35. Ressuspend pellet with
buffer F.

DESALTING
36. After equilibrating Sephadex G-25 fine column with 3 x column volume buffer F, load the sample and elute with buffer F, taking aliquots and checking the amount of protein with Bradford reagent (monitor the development of blue colour by eye for a qualitative assessment, not necessary to read absorbance).
37. Pool samples with highest protein content.
38. Once desalting of the sample is complete, wash column with 2 column volumes of
NaOH, rinse with water, and re-equilibrate with 2-3 column volumes of buffer A.
39. Store pooled fractions at
.

source.body: It is not necessary to add proteases inhibitors as now it is a pure protein.
Start adding of buffer F and collecting aliquots. Check TSP “by eye”. In our hands, samples pooled were from fractions 3 to 6.

For storage, antimicrobial agents should be added to the column to prevent contamination ( phenyl mercuric salts, thimerosal, chlorobutanol, chlorhexine, sodium azide, or ethanol are acceptable).
When necessary, the gel can be removed from the column and sterilized by autoclaving.

Before freezing samples check the activity (3-PGA comsumption in presence of increasing concentrations of 2,3dPGA using the PK-LDH protocol in this series). It is important to keep an aliquot of previous dPGM preparation to compare results obtained.

source.description:
APPENDIX 1. Purification of plasmid DNA, aka minipreps for sequencing
Following Day 3
  1. Prepare a glycerol stock of the culture (for long term storage): combine 300 μL culture + 300 μL 30% glycerol in a 2 mL screw-cap tube, mix gently by inversion. Store at -80°C.
  2. Spin the remaining cell culture down for 10 min at 4000 rpm, room temperature.
  3. Pour off the supernatant into the bacterial waste bottle and leave tubes upside down and open on blue roll for a few minutes to drain any excess supernatant.
  4. Resuspend the pellets in 250 μl Resuspension Solution (stored at 4°C) and transfer to labelled 1.5 ml tubes.
  5. Vortex briefly to eliminate all clumps of bacteria.
  6. Add 250 μl Lysis Solution, invert gently 4-6 times to mix, then incubate at RT for 4 min.
  7. Add 350 μl Neutralisation Solution, invert gently 4-6 times to mix.
  8. Spin in the microcentrifuge at 13,400 rpm for 5 min. Transfer the supernatant to a labelled spin column.
  9. Spin in the microcentrifuge at 13,400 rpm for 1 min. Discard the flow-through.
  10. Wash the column by adding 500 μl Wash Solution.
  11. Spin in the microcentrifuge at 13,400 rpm for 1 min. Discard the flow-through.
  12. Wash the column for a second time by adding another 500 μl Wash Solution.
  13. Spin in the microcentrifuge at 13,400 rpm for 1 min. Discard the flow-through.
  14. Spin the empty column in the microcentrifuge at 13,400 rpm for 1 min.
  15. Transfer the column to a clean labelled 1.5 ml tube, add 55 μl SDW to the middle of the column and incubate at RT for 2 min. Spin in the microcentrifuge at 13,400 rpm for 1 min. Discard the column.
  16. Determine the concentration and purity of pDNA using a nanodrop (DNA concentration, 260:230 nm ratio)
  18. APPENDIX 2. SDS-Page for checking protein in different fractions
  20. UNINDUCED Sample (from Induction step 10.)
  21. Thaw pellet. Resuspend in about
  23. of Lysis Buffer.
  24. Vortex and incubate on ice.
  25. Rupture the cells and DNA by sonicating the suspension until solution becomes easy to pipette. Insert sonicator half way into the solution and apply 3 x 5 s bursts, with the tube always on ice. Pause for some seconds between each burst.
  26. Centrifuge at 4000 rpm for 10 min at 4°C. Keep SN and pellet.
  27. Quantify the total soluble portein (TSP) in the supernatant. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min. Dilute to 0.5 mgTSP/mL with blank (Lysis buffer + Loading Buffer).
  28. Resuspend pellet in
  30. of Lysis Buffer. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min.
  32. INDUCED Sample (from Lysis step #21.)
  33. After sonication, centrifuge at 4000 rpm for 10 min at 4°C. Keep supernatant and pellet.
  34. Quantify TSP in the supernatant. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min. Dilute to 0.5 mgTSP/mL with blank (Lysis buffer + Loading Buffer).
APPENDIX 2. SDS-Page for checking protein in different fractions
UNINDUCED Sample (from Induction step 10.)
Thaw pellet. Resuspend in about
of Lysis Buffer.
  1. Vortex and incubate on ice.
  2. Rupture the cells and DNA by sonicating the suspension until solution becomes easy to pipette. Insert sonicator half way into the solution and apply 3 x 5 s bursts, with the tube always on ice. Pause for some seconds between each burst.
  3. Centrifuge at 4000 rpm for 10 min at 4°C. Keep SN and pellet.
  4. Quantify the total soluble portein (TSP) in the supernatant. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min. Dilute to 0.5 mgTSP/mL with blank (Lysis buffer + Loading Buffer).
  5. Resuspend pellet in
  7. of Lysis Buffer. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min.
  9. INDUCED Sample (from Lysis step #21.)
  10. After sonication, centrifuge at 4000 rpm for 10 min at 4°C. Keep supernatant and pellet.
  11. Quantify TSP in the supernatant. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min. Dilute to 0.5 mgTSP/mL with blank (Lysis buffer + Loading Buffer).
Resuspend pellet in
of Lysis Buffer. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min.
INDUCED Sample (from Lysis step #21.)
  1. After sonication, centrifuge at 4000 rpm for 10 min at 4°C. Keep supernatant and pellet.
  2. Quantify TSP in the supernatant. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min. Dilute to 0.5 mgTSP/mL with blank (Lysis buffer + Loading Buffer).
Resuspend pellet in
of Lysis Buffer. Add Loading Buffer (proportion of 4:5 LB:Sample), incubate at 95°C for 4 min.
Run samples on SDS-Page and stain with coomassie blue to visulaise proteins.
APPENDIX 3. Step-tactin purification process, as detailed in the manufacturer’s instructions:
APPENDIX 4. Regeneration of Strep-tactin resin, as detailed in the manufacturer’s instructions:

source.body: In our hands, loading 2 mg TSP/lane provides clear protein bands. The protein is expected to be in the soluble fraction, but some protein can be seen in the insoluble fraction. Note that the gel is just qualitative for the insoluble protein fraction.

materials.name: 10x Buffer R; Strep-Tactin® Regeneration Buffer with HABA

description: This protocol describes the purification of dPGM based on Fraser et al. (1999) and Scales et al. (2014) with modifications. Some steps of the purification protocol were also informed by van de Loo & Salvucci (1996), Schmidt & Skerra (2007), and White & Fothergill-Gilmore (1992).
